revision.text:
'''Academic drama''' refers to a theatrical movement that emerged in the mid 16th century during [[the Renaissance]]. Dedicated to the study of classical dramas for the purpose of higher education, universities in England began to produce the plays of [[Sophocles]], [[Euripides]], and [[Seneca the Younger]] (among others) in the Greek and Roman languages, as well as neoclassical dramas. These classical and neoclassical productions were performed by young scholars at universities in [[Cambridge]] and [[Oxford]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Boas|first1=Fredrick|title=University Drama in the Tudor Age|date=1966|publisher=Benjamin Blom Inc.|location=New York|pages=16–19}}</ref> Other European countries, such as Spain and Italy adapted classical plays into a mixture of Latin and vernacular dramas. These Spanish and Italian adaptations were used in teaching morals in schools and colleges.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Leicester|first1=Bradner|title=The Latin Drama of the Renaissance (1340–1640)|journal=Studies in the Renaissance|date=1957|volume=4|pages=31–54|doi=10.2307/2857139|jstor=2857139}}</ref> The intellectual development of dramas in schools, universities, and [[Inns of Court]] in Europe allowed the emergence of the great playwrights of the late 16th century.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brooke|first1=Tucker|title=Latin Drama in Renaissance England|journal=ELH|date=December 1946|volume=13|issue=4|pages=233–240|doi=10.2307/2871446|jstor=2871446}}</ref>
== Academic drama at Oxford University == [[File:Hall of Christ Church, Oxford.jpg|thumb|Hall of Christ Church, Oxford]] The history of academic drama at [[Oxford University]] may be traced back to the mid 16th century. While there are records indicating dramatic performances were performed prior, dramatic production greatly increased in the 16th century.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Robertson|first1=Roderick|title=Oxford Theatre in Tudor Times|journal=Educational Theatre Journal|date=March 1969|volume=21|issue=1|pages=41–2|doi=10.2307/3205776|jstor=3205776}}</ref> Academic dramas were performed in Christ Church and St. John's College at Oxford.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nelson|first1=Alan H.|title=Emulating Royalty: Cambridge, Oxford, and the Inns of Court|journal=Shakespeare Studies|date=2009|volume=37|pages=67–76|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=44129019&site=ehost-live|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref> The plays produced at Oxford were originally written in Latin, based on classical models. Used to teach playwriting and acting, these plays were written by both the students and instructors. In performance, audiences typically consisted of fellow students, though visits from royalty occasionally occurred. Among these royals were [[Queen Elizabeth I]] and [[King James I]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Robertson|first1=Roderick|title=Oxford Theatre in Tudor Times|journal=Educational Theatre Journal|date=March 1969|volume=21|issue=1|pages=4–46|doi=10.2307/3205776|jstor=3205776}}</ref>
It is evident that academic drama at Oxford was highly regarded as a crucial part of the educational experience. The university covered all performance expenses. Additionally, no entrance fees were charged.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Robertson|first1=Roderick|title=Oxford Theatre in Tudor Times|journal=Educational Theatre Journal|date=March 1969|volume=21|issue=1|page=47|doi=10.2307/3205776|jstor=3205776}}</ref>
== Academic drama at Cambridge University == [[File:St. John's College, Cambridge, England-LCCN2002696460.jpg|thumb|St. John's College, Cambridge, England-LCCN2002696460]] In producing academic drama, the colleges at [[Cambridge University]] were decidedly confined to performing Latin works. When Queen Elizabeth I sent requests to both Cambridge and Oxford requesting the performance of an English comedy, she was met with a decline from Cambridge. Cambridge replied they did not use plays in English.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brooke|first1=Tucker|title=Latin Drama in Renaissance England|journal=ELH|date=December 1946|volume=13|issue=4|page=234|doi=10.2307/2871446|jstor=2871446}}</ref> However, it must be noted that though Cambridge did not indulge the Queen with an English comedy, they were not opposed to neo-Latin comedies. The majority of surviving English neo-Latin university dramas were performed at Cambridge.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Greenwood|first1=David|title=The Staging of Neo-Latin Plays in Sixteenth Century England|journal=Educational Theatre Journal|date=December 1964|volume=16|issue=4|page=323|doi=10.2307/3204572|jstor=3204572}}</ref> Performances at Cambridge were in Latin<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brooke|first1=Tucker|title=Latin Drama in Renaissance England|journal=ELH|date=December 1946|volume=13|issue=4|page=323|doi=10.2307/2871446|jstor=2871446}}</ref> and the material of choice was the classics. Folios found at St. John's at Cambridge show records of costumes housed for performances. It is believed these costumes were used in the acting of classical works by [[Aristophanes]] and [[Terence]], as well as in [[morality plays]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Billington|first1=Sandra|title=Sixteenth-Century Drama in St. John's College, Cambridge|journal=The Review of English Studies |series=New Series|date=February 1978|volume=29|issue=113|pages=8–9|jstor=514357|doi=10.1093/res/xxix.113.1}}</ref>
== Academic drama at the Inns of Court == The [[Inns of Court]] are referred to as the third university of England.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nelson|first1=Alan H.|title=Emulating Royalty: Cambridge, Oxford, and the Inns of Court|journal=Shakespeare Studies|date=2009|volume=37|pages=67–76|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=44129019&site=ehost-live|accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref> Inns of Court were where practicing lawyers and law students gathered to eat, socialize, gain legal education, board, and be entertained. There were four of these Inns of Court: [[Gray's Inn]], [[Inner Temple]], [[Lincoln's Inn]], and [[Middle Temple]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Prest|first1=Wilfrid R.|title=The Inns of Court under Elizabeth I and the Early Stuarts 1590–1640|date=1972|publisher=Longman|location=London|isbn=0-582-50831-2}}</ref> In contrast to Cambridge and Oxford, who produced theatre as a literary study, the London Inns of Court produced theatre as a means of entertainment.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Green|first1=A. Wigfall|title=The Inns of Court and Early English Drama|date=1931|publisher=Benjamin Blom|location=New York}}</ref> Beginning around 1587, the Inns of Court produced [[masques]] and revels, yet another contrast from the Oxford and Cambridge plays.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nelson|first1=Alan H.|title=Emulating Royalty: Cambridge, Oxford, and the Inns of Court|journal=Shakespeare Studies|date=2009|volume=37|pages=67–76|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=44129019&site=ehost-live|accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref> Until the end of the 17th century, these performances typically took the form of masques written by law students at the Inns of Court. Once the Inns of Court transitioned from masques to plays, the so-called third university served as a cradle for classical English drama. Eventually, by the early 17th century, writers such as [[Ben Jonson]] and [[William Shakespeare]] began producing English comedies at the Inns of Court, thus expanding the range of materials performed.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Green|first1=A. Wigfall|title=The Inns of Court and Early English Drama|date=1931|publisher=Benjamin Blom|location=New York}}</ref> After 1614, the masques were written and designed by professionals; simultaneously the new emerging dramas were written and performed by professional theatre practitioners.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Prest|first1=Wilfrid R.|title=The Inns of Court under Elizabeth I and the Early Stuarts 1590–1640|date=1972|publisher=Longman|location=London|isbn=0-582-50831-2}}</ref> Due to the close proximity to the English court, nobility frequently attended the performances at the Inns of Court.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nelson|first1=Alan H.|title=Emulating Royalty: Cambridge, Oxford, and the Inns of Court|journal=Shakespeare Studies|date=2009|volume=37|pages=67–76|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=44129019&site=ehost-live|accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref>
== Classical drama performed == Academic drama was formed as an educational tool, not only to advance the arts, but to teach classical literature and language. Key subject matter for performance were classical [[drama]]s of ancient Greece and Rome. Prominent playwrights whose works were performed as part of the academic drama tradition include [[Aristophanes]], [[Plautus]], [[Seneca the younger]], and [[Terrence]]. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:auto; margin:auto;" |- ! == Neo-Latin/English drama performed == Neo-Latin or [[New Latin]] dramas as they may also be referred to, were plays written in Latin by students and professors at Oxford, Cambridge, and the Inns of Court. Subject matter ranged from religious, to satirical, to mythological.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Boas|first1=Fredrick|title=University Drama in the Tudor Age|date=1966|publisher=Benjamin Blom Inc.|location=New York|pages=16–19}}</ref> Eventually these original plays began to be written in English, preparing the way for the English drama of the Elizabethan Age.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brooke|first1=Tucker|title=Latin Drama in Renaissance England|journal=ELH|date=December 1946|volume=13|issue=4|pages=233–240|doi=10.2307/2871446|jstor=2871446}}</ref> {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:auto; margin:auto;" |- ! The '''American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors and Their Descendants,''' also known as the '''American Gathering,''' is the largest organization of [[Holocaust]] survivors in [[North America]]. It functions as an [[umbrella organization]] for survivor resources, offering both services and advocacy. The American Gathering is active in [[Holocaust]] remembrance, education and commemoration programs. From 1983 onwards, the organization has held national reunion events.
== History == [[Benjamin Meed]] and his wife Vladka Meed helped to organize the first World Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors in Israel in June 1981.<ref name=NYTimes-VladkaMeed-Obit-2012>{{cite news|last1=Berger|first1=Joseph|title=Vladka Meed, Who Infiltrated Warsaw Ghetto, Dies at 90|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/25/world/vladka-meed-who-infiltrated-warsaw-ghetto-dies-at-90.html?_r=0|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 November 2012}}</ref><ref name=NYTimes-SamBloch-1981>{{cite news|last1=Brozan|first1=Nadine|title=Holocaust Survivors on 'Pilgrimage of Rememberance(sic)'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/15/style/holocaust-survivors-on-pilgrimage-of-rememberance.html|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 June 1981}}</ref> Inspired by and an outcome of that event, in 1981, the Meeds and other fellow [[Holocaust]] survivors established a North American organization called The American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors and Their Descendants.<ref name=NYSun-BenjaminMeed-Obit-2006>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Stephen|title=Benjamin Meed, 88, Organized Holocaust Survivors|url=http://www.nysun.com/obituaries/benjamin-meed-88-organized-holocaust-survivors/42352/|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=[[New York Sun]]|date=26 October 2006}}</ref> The American Gathering organized a reunion event for survivors that was held in Washington, D.C. in April 1983.<ref name=BostonGlobe-Reunion-1983>{{cite news|last1=Trausch|first1=Susan|title=Holocaust Survivors Gather to Piece the Puzzle Together|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/294115949|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=[[Boston Globe]]|date=10 April 1983|ISSN=0743-1791}}{{subscription required}}</ref> The 1983 event was organized by Hirsch Altusky, Sam Bloch, Fred Diament, Roman Kent, [[Benjamin Meed]], Ernest Michel, James Rapp, Norbert Wollheim and Solomon Zynstein. Over 20,000 survivors and their families attended this first event.<ref name=FromHolocausttoNewLife-1985>{{cite book|last1=American Gathering of Holocaust Survivors|title=From Holocaust to New Life: A Documentary Volume Depicting the Proceedings and Events of the American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors, Washington DC, April 1983–Nissan 5743|date=1985|publisher=American Gathering of Holocaust Survivors|location=New York, NY|OCLC=15069152}}</ref>
The initial focus of the organization was to hold national and local reunions of survivors and their families<ref name=NYTimes-BenjaminMeed-Obit-2006>{{cite news|last1=Fox|first1=Margalit|title=Benjamin Meed, 88, Who Was a Key Advocate for Holocaust Survivors, Dies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/26/obituaries/26meed.html|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 October 2006}}</ref> and to combat isolation that survivors sometimes experienced, even within the wider Jewish community.<ref name=NYTimes-VladkaMeed-Obit-2012 /> The 1983 reunion was led by honorary chair, [[Elie Wiesel]],<ref name=NYTimes-Reunion-1983>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Judith|title=Holocaust Survivors, in U.S. Reunion, Ask World to Remember|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/us/holocaust-survivors-in-us-reunion-ask-world-to-remember.html|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=12 April 1983}}</ref> with a speech given by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]].<ref name=AmPresidencyProject-Reagan-1983>{{cite web|last1=Reagan|first1=Ronald|title=Remarks to the American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=41171|website=American Presidency Project|publisher=[[University of California Santa Barbara]]|accessdate=16 May 2015|date=11 April 1983}}</ref>
The American Gathering, located in [[New York City]], is a member of other organizations such as the [[World Jewish Congress]], the World Jewish Restitution Organization, the [[Jewish Community Relations Council]] and the [[Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations]]. In that capacity, its mission is to use its [[moral authority]] to influence issues of importance to the survivor community and to the world Jewish community.
== Projects ==
=== Survivors Registry === The Benjamin and Vladka Meed Registry of Holocaust Survivors was established in 1981 to document the names of survivors who came to the Americas after [[World War II]].<ref name=BostonGlobe-ConferenceRegistry-1983>{{cite news|last1=Trausch|first1=Susan|title=Holocaust Survivors Seek the Past in 45,000 Names|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/294183638|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=[[Boston Globe]]|date=12 April 1983|ISSN=0743-1791}}{{subscription required}}</ref> It is the only registry of its kind. In 1993, it was moved to the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] (USHMM).<ref name=MJH-SurvivorsRegistry>{{cite web|title=Survivors Registry|url=http://www.mjhnyc.org/a_remembrance_registry.html|website=[[Museum of Jewish Heritage]]|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> In cooperation with the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]], the American Gathering continues to manage the database and to seek new registrants via its quarterly newspaper ''Together'' and its website, among other venues. The Registry includes over 200,000 records related to survivors and their families and is a resource for Holocaust historians and scholars, as well as families looking for lost relatives.<ref name=JewishRootsInUkraineMoldava-UKFwd-1999>{{cite book|last1=Berenbaum|first1=Michael (Forward)|editor1-last=Weiner|editor1-first=Miriam|editor2-last=Ukrainian State Archives (in cooperation with)|editor3-last=Moldovan National Archives (in cooperation with)|title=Jewish Roots in Ukraine and Moldova: Pages from the Past and Archival Inventories|date=1999|publisher=Miriam Weiner Routes to Roots Foundation|location=Secaucus, NJ|isbn=978-0-96-565081-6|pages=ix-x|url=http://www.rtrfoundation.org/webart/UKFwd.pdf|oclc=607423469}}</ref>
=== Holocaust and Jewish Resistance Teachers' Program === Initiated in 1984 by [[Vladka Meed]] and jointly administered by the American Gathering and the USHMM, the [http://hajrtp.org/ Holocaust and Jewish Resistance Teachers' Program] is a two-week summer program for middle school and high school teachers, both Jewish and non-Jewish alike, on trips to Holocaust sites in [[Poland]] and to [[Israel]]. Participating scholars come from [[Yad Vashem]] in [[Jerusalem]], the Study Center at Kibbutz Lohamei HaGeta'ot, and the USHMM in Washington, D.C. to speak with teachers selected for the program.<ref name=HoustonChronicle-HAJRTP-2012>{{cite news|last1=Meeks|first1=Flori|title=Clear Lake man changes outlook on life after Holocaust study trip|url=http://www.chron.com/bayarea/news/article/Clear-Lake-man-changes-outlook-on-life-after-3932382.php|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|date=9 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=BocaRatonTrib-HAJRTP-2014>{{cite news|last1=Barnes|first1=Tiye|title=Spanish River High School Teacher to Attend Holocaust Seminar|url=http://www.bocaratontribune.com/bocaratonnews/2014/06/spanish-river-high-school-teacher-to-attend-holocaust-seminar-3/|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=The Boca Raton Tribune|date=21 June 2014}}</ref> A biannual Alumni Conference of the program's participants further reinforces its goals to foster remembrance and toleration.
=== Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany === The American Gathering is on the Board of Directors of the [[Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany]], an organization that seeks restitution from the governments of Germany and Austria. The current negotiating committee is composed solely of survivors and chaired by the American Gathering's chairman Roman Kent, the restitution provides health care and assistance to survivors in desperate need.
=== ''Together'' === Founded in 1985, ''Together'' is the official publication of the American Gathering. With a circulation of approximately 85,000, it reflects the collective voice of survivors, the second and third generations, and includes news, opinions, information on education, commemorations, events, book reviews, announcements, searches, and articles on history and personal remembrance. Contributors include professional writers, poets, thinkers, historians and Holocaust scholars.
=== Community outreach === The American Gathering actively assists survivors on a daily basis. Whether it is through sitting on the Claims Conference, Self-Help Boards, manning an office to offer information, applications for assistance or interfacing with other related agencies on behalf of survivors, the American Gathering does its utmost to ensure that survivor issues are addressed.
=== National Holocaust commemorations and memorials === The collective and individual initiatives of the American Gathering leadership has fostered Holocaust commemoration, remembrance events and the establishment of Holocaust memorials in many communities throughout the United States and in almost every State House in the Union. While the American Gathering continues to sponsor its own annual commemoration program with the Museum of Jewish Heritage and WAGRO, it has been instrumental in the creation of the ongoing Holocaust programs at both the United Nations and the U.S. Congress.

'''Antonio Arrúe Zarauz''' (1903–1976) was a Spanish [[Carlist]] politician and a [[Basque people|Basque]] cultural activist.
==Family and youth== [[File:Alapasagasti.jpg|thumbnail|left|Arrúe's family house, [[Asteasu]]]] Antonio Arrúe Zarauz<ref>Not to be confused with Antonio Arrué Peiró, a contemporary Spanish martyr (1908–1936) beatified by the Catholic Church (see [http://www.donorione.org/Public/ContentPage/content.asp?hdnIdContent=98 here]) and also a controversial figure related to the Spanish Civil War.</ref> was born in the Elizmendi quarter of Asteasu,<ref>Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''Antonio Arrue, el carlista que colaboró en el relanzamiento de Euskaltzaindia'', [in:] ''Euskera'' 56 (2011), p. 849</ref> a small [[town]] [[Distance|near]] [[Tolosa, Spain|Tolosa]] in the [[Gipuzkoa]] [[Province (Spain)|province]], in the [[1833 territorial division of Spain|region]] then known as [[Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)|Vascongadas]]. None of the sources consulted offers any information on his parents, except that his father, [[Juan Arrúe]], was the first [[organist]] in the [[Human settlement|local]] [[St Peter|San Pedro]] [[Church (building)|church]];<ref>winning the competition of 1888, aiurri.com service available [http://www.aiurri.com/berriak.php?id_edukia=17757 here]; see also Ángel Sagardia Sagardia, ''Ángel Cabanas Erausquin'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'' available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/28229 here] and aramburu blog available [http://aramburu.blogspot.com/2010_05_01_archive.html here]</ref> he also served in a number of nearby [[village]]s and towns giving [[lesson]]s.<ref>Antonio Zavala, ''Presentación'', [in:] ''Antonio Arrue. Idaztiak eta hitzaldiak'', Bilbo 2008, {{ISBN|9788495438423}}, p. XII</ref> Correct spelling of Antonio's mother’s surname is disputed.<ref>Arrúe’s segundo apellido is usually spelled as “Zarauz”, compare the official Cortes service available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%289240%29.NDIP. here], though some authors prefer the “Zarautz” version, see Joxemiel Bidador, ''Antonio Arrue Zarautz'', a 2000 entry [in:] ''zubitega'' service available [http://zubitegia.armiarma.com/?p=bid-106 here];</ref> It is not clear whether the family was in any way related to a number of known contemporary Basques bearing the same name, esp. the [[José Arrue|Arrúe Valle brothers]]<ref>Jose, Ramiro and Ricardo, see their personal entries at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'' available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/5503 here], [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/5503 here] and [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/5497 here]</ref> and the [[Franciscan]] musician, [[José Arrúe (musician, not painter)|José Arrúe]].<ref>see ''Arrue, José de (1884-1960)'' entry at ''eresbil.com'' service available [http://www.eresbil.com/fmi/xsl/Musikaste/esp/browserecord_compositor_aa.xsl;jsessionid=85D70FBD1082727E17989B07946D3194?-lay=Musikastegeneral&ID_BIO1=EEARR030&-find=-find here]</ref> Antonio and his two sisters, Eleuteria and Dolores,<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XII</ref> were raised in a profoundly Catholic ambience.<ref>though somatimes his relations with the clergy remained thorny, see Luis Villasante Kortabitarte, ''Antonio Arrue jauna hil zaigu'' [in:] ''argia.eus'' service available [http://www.argia.eus/mendea/pertso/76arrue.htm here]</ref>
The young Antonio obtained his bachillerato in the [[Lecároz colleg]]e, run by the [[Capuchin friars|Capuchin]] friars in [[Elizondo, Navarre|Elizondo]], in the Navarrese region of [[Baztan (comarca)|Valle de Baztán]], few miles from the French frontier.<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XII, also Bernardo Estornés Lasa, ''Antonio Arrúe Zarauz'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entzikopedia'', available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/5504 here]</ref> In the early 1920s he studied in [[Oviedo]], enrolled at the Faculty of Law in the [[University of Oviedo|local university]].<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 855, Estornés Lasa, ''Antonio Arrúe Zarauz''</ref> None of the sources consulted gives exact dates of his academic period. Following graduation he returned to Gipuzkoa and started the career as a [[lawyer]]. It is not clear when and where he opened the office; he is first reported by the newspapers as “a young lawyer from Asteasu” in the early 1930s.
In 1941 Arrúe married María Teresa Salazar, a native of Tolosa.<ref>during their engagement period Arrúe travelled on bike from his home to Villabona, half-way between Asteasu and Tolosa, to meet his fiancée on "neutral ground", see Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 849, see also ''ABC'' 11.10.05, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2005/10/11/042.html here]</ref> The couple settled in San Sebastián; Antonio continued with his law practice, opening the business in the very centre of the city;<ref>first at calle Legazpi, later move to calle de Garibay, Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 855</ref> gradually he specialized in rural rent and heritage issues, working with a number of local companies, associations and institutions.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 855, Bernardo Estornés Lasa, ''Antonio Arrúe Zarauz''</ref> María initially served as a secretary in his law office, later on to work as a [[seamstress]] in the [[garment]] shop, run by her mother.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 855</ref> They had 3 daughters, Maite, María Ignacia and María Carmen. Their only son, [[Juan María Arrúe Salazar]], became a well known [[Donostia-San Sebastián, Guipúzcoa|donostian]] lawyer and is referred to as a specialist in [[urbanism]]o.<ref>see ''laboratoriodefilosofia'' service available [http://www.laboratoriodefilosofia.net/actividades/filosofia_y_ciudad_arrue_mingot.html here], also ''infoempresa'' service availavle [http://www.infoempresa.com/directivo/arrue-salazar-juan-maria/ here]; like his grandfather, Juan Arrúe Salazar also used to plays organs in Asteasu, see ''[[Diario Vasco]]'' 29.06.11, available [http://www.diariovasco.com/20110629/local/asteasu-celebro-pedro-buena-201106291629.html here]</ref>
==Early career== [[File:Portada de La Constancia, 1 de julio de 1903.jpg|thumbnail|160px|''La Constancia'']] It is not clear whether Arrúe has inherited [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] outlook from his ancestors – like most Carlists in [[Southern Basque Country|Basque-Navarrese area]] have – or whether he embraced it during the schooling and academic years. None of the sources consulted offers also any clue as to which branch of the movement he joined in the 1920s, the [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Jaimistas]], the [[Juan Vázquez de Mella|Mellistas]] or the [[Integrism (Spain)|Integristas]], though it is the latter group which seems most probable. Asteasu was in the very centre of the Integrist national stronghold, composed of Tolosa and [[Azpeitia]] districts;<ref>see Javier Real Cuesta, ''El Carlismo Vasco 1876-1900'', Madrid 1985, {{ISBN|8432305103}}, 9788432305108, pp. 113-127, 254-269; in the Azpeitia district the Integrists won 13 out of 22 Cortes mandes conquered during the Restoration age</ref> an Anastasio Arrúe was jefe of the local Tolosan Integrist junta, and a Pedro Arrúe was its treasurer;<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 22.05.06, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000259954&page=1 here]; there were also other members of the Arrue family active as Integrist supporters in the district, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 07.08.95, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000181553&page= here] 1</ref> Antonio’s father as an organist was closely related to the parochial clergy; finally, in the early 1930s Antonio commenced collaboration with ''[[:es:La Constancia (1897-1936)|La Constancia]]'',<ref>Juan San Martin, ''Antonio Arrue'', [in:] ''Egan'' 1/6 (1976), p. 16, available [http://andima.armiarma.com/egan/egan58/iruegan580017.htm here]</ref> the local Gipuzkoan Integrist daily, later editing its newly introduced section in [[Basque language|Basque]].<ref>some authors claim it was as early as in 1932, see San Martin 1976, Bidador 2000; bibliographical entry of ''La Constancia'' at the San Sebastián digital press archive claims the Basque section was introduced in 1934, see [http://liburutegidigitala.donostiakultura.com/Liburutegiak/catalogo_ficha.php?dp_id=113 here]</ref>
Arrúe became a public figure after the three Traditionalist streams merged into a united Carlist organization, [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]], in 1932. In 1933 he was already reported as an active speaker at local Carlist meetings, mostly in minor Gipuzkoan localities like [[Itsasondo|Isasondo]].<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'', 28.08.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000515996&page=3 here], also ''El Siglo Futuro'' 07.10.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000516376&page=3 here]</ref> In the summer of 1934 his activity became indeed hectic and was recorded also in major cities like San Sebastian.<ref>in May he spoke in San Sebastian (see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 05.05.34 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000524679&page=3 here]), in June in Ganza (''El Siglo Futuro'' 09.06.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000526142&page=3 here]) and Goyaz (''El Siglo Futuro'' 15.06.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000526388&page=3 here]), in July in Bedayo (''El Siglo Futuro'' 12.07.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000527486&page=3 here]) and Zarauz (''El Siglo Futuro'' 14.07.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000527582&page=3 here]), in August in Renteria (''El Siglo Futuro'' 18.08.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000529027&page=3 here])</ref> Soon gaining recognition as “notable orador”,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 18.08.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000529027&page=3 here]</ref> Arrúe delivered vibrant [[harangue]]s in Basque that sparked the enthusiasm of the audience.<ref>see e.g. ''El Siglo Futuro'' 28.08.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000529424&page=3 here]</ref> His speeches covered key Carlist topics: siding with the Church against [[Second Spanish Republic|Republican]] secularization, hailing Gipuzkoan [[Baserri|caserios]] as bulwarks of loyalty, defending traditionalist monarchy as a warrant of regional [[fuero]]s and confronting [[Basque nationalism]] as illusory and deceptive; there were also some social threads present.<ref>compare ''El Siglo Futuro'' 09.08.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000552817&page=20 here], ''La Epoca'' 23.12.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001170525&page=3 here], and especially ''El Siglo Futuro'' 23.12.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000569192&page=7 here]</ref> He spoke firmly against the [[:es:Estatuto Vasco-Navarro|autonomy draft]], denouncing it as "antivasco, antiforal y exótico".<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 09.08.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000552817&page=20 here]</ref> Nominated secretary of the Carlist Junta Provincial of Gipuzkoa,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 16.07.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000527634&page=2 here]</ref> he continued with public appearances – already dubbed “infatigable secretario” – throughout 1935<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 14.08.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000553374&page=9 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 20.08.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000554054&page=9 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 16.10.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000561026&page=22 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 01.11.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000562917&page=11 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 02.11.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000563060&page=9 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 04.11.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000563207&page=12 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 10.12.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000567620&page=22 here]</ref> and early 1936.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.02.36, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000575441&page=12 here]</ref>
==Civil War== [[File:Gipuzkoa frontline 1936.gif|thumbnail|left|campaign in Gipuzkoa]] It is not clear whether Arrúe contributed either to Carlist military buildup or political preparations to the [[Spanish coup of July 1936|July 1936 coup]], as neither himself nor any of the sources consulted provides any related information.<ref>Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''Carlos Hugo frente a Juan Carlos: La solución federal para España que Franco rechazó'', Madrid 2014, {{ISBN|8477682658}}, 9788477682653, p. 229 states vaguely that Arrúe contributed to insurgency preparations, though he gives neither a source nor any details</ref> Once it became clear the insurgency failed in Gipuzkoa he went into hiding<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 850, Zavala 2008, p. XIII</ref> and resurfaced when the Carlist troops [[Campaign of Gipuzkoa|conquered the province]]. As the Junta Provincial was transformed into the wartime Traditionalist provincial body, Junta Carlista de Guerra of Gipuzkoa, Arrúe resumed his duties of its secretary.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 850</ref> Some time late 1936 or early 1937 he became acting president of this body, as its February 1937 documents are already signed by him as "presidente en funciones".<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 852</ref>
Arrúe soon became disillusioned by military rule in the [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalist zone]], growing particularly anxious about preponderance of [[Falange Española y de las JONS|Falange]] in Gipuzkoa and about centralizing designs of the regime, perceived as a threat to Traditionalism, Basque culture and provincial identity.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 851</ref> Already in October 1936 the Gipuzkoan Junta Carlista de Guerra, animated by Arrúe, voiced publicly against composition of the provincial [[comision gestora (appointed local governing body)|comision gestora]],<ref>the Junta published its statement in ''La Voz de España'', declaring that “con relación a la nota de la F .E. de las JONS aparecida en Unidad, la Junta Carlista de Guerra de Guipúzcoa desea hacer público que lamenta no poder adoptar actitud análoga a la que se expresa en dicha nota, por no haber recibido invitación alguna del Excmo. Sr. Gobernador Civil para participar en la nueva Gestora Provincial . Por consiguiente esta Junta no ha facilitado ningún nombre para la provisión de puestos en el referido organismo”, quoted after Félix Luengo Teixedor, ''La formación del poder franquista en Guipúzcoa (1937-1945)'', [in:] ''Geronimo de Uztariz'' 4 (1990), p. 86</ref> bluntly stating that there are two wars: one in the trenches, and one in the corridors of power.<ref>“Hay dos guerras, la de las trincheras, donde se expone la vida y se juega con la muerte, y la de las ciudades, donde se exponen cargos y se juega con los nombres (. . .) En la retaguardia hay una guerra sórdida y miserable, en la que empuja y se trabaja arteramente por medrar y subir, por colocarse y brillar”, quoted after Teixedor 1990, p. 86</ref> Early 1937 he tried to co-ordinate a joint effort of [[Navarre]]se, Gipuzkoan and [[Biscay]] juntas, aimed at countering falangism and ensuring that provincial fueros do not suffer.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 851, further details in Teixidor 1990, pp. 84-86</ref> Faced with growing threat of amalgamating Carlism within a monopolist state party, just a week between the [[:es:Decreto de Unificación|Unification Decree]] he signed a circular, urging every Gipuzkoan Carlist to maintain loyalty to the Comunión.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 852</ref> [[File:Bandera FE JONS.png|thumbnail|Falangist standard]] Once [[Francisco Franco|Franco]] decreed abolishment of all parties and their unification within [[Falange Española Tradicionalista y de las JONS|FET]], Arrúe decided simply to ignore it. When the new Carlist regent, [[Xavier, Duke of Parma and Piacenza|Don Javier]], entered Spain in mid-May, Arrúe accompanied him across Gipuzkoa. On May 19, 1937 he took part in first of the two most emotional moments of his political career: Don Javier swearing at the [[Gernikako Arbola|Guernica oak]] to conform to and protect the traditional Basque fueros.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 852; the oath was taken by capelan of the Requetés and the pason of Ezquiroz, Fermín Erice, Martorell Pérez 2014, p. 229, see also [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uhK1ER3B4Hg video homage at 02:52]</ref> The pledge soon suffered a major setback when, following the conquest of Biscay, Franco scrapped the provincial [[concierto economico]] in June 1937.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 853; other sources claim it was in July 37, see Teixedor 1990, p. 88</ref> Standoff between the military and Carlism continued as Don Javier re-entered Spain in November; Arrúe was appointed his personal secretary,<ref>Martorell Pérez 2014, p. 229</ref> touring the frontlines and making 4,000 km across [[Basque Country (autonomous region)|Vascongadas]], [[Castile (historical region)|Castile]], [[Extremadura]] and [[Andalusia]].<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 853</ref> In December 1937 the adventure came to an abrupt end when in [[Granada]] Arrúe was reached by the military detention order; only thanks to intervention of collaborationist Carlists he was allowed to make it to the [[Burgos]] prison himself instead of having been escorted in handcuffs by [[Guardia Civil]].<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 853-4; Don Javier was expulsed from Spain soon afterwards, Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Valencia 2009, p. 154</ref> It is not clear how much time he spent behind bars; released, he returned to Asteasu to lead Carlist opposition to falangisation of the province.<ref>Gobernacion civil was already fully controlled by FET, though Carlism remained in control of Diputación Provincial, see Teixedor 1990, p. 88; key front-office Carlists in Gipuzkoa were at that time Julio Muñoz Aguilar (jefe of provincial FET), Fidel Azurza (president of Diputación, jefe provincial de FET), Juan José Pradera (director of La Voz de Espana). Elías Querejeta (jefe of provincial FET), Lus Ruiz de Prada (president of Diputación) and Fernando Aramburu (president of Diputación), Teixedor 1990; another author describes them as “poco representativos”, see Mercedes Vázquez de Prada Tiffe, ''La reorganización del carlismo vasco en los sesenta: entre la pasividad y el "separatismo"'', [in:] ''Vasconia. Cuadernos de Historia-Geografía'', 38 (2012), p. 1123</ref>
==Early Francoism== [[File:Franco Tolosa 1948.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Francisco Franco|Franco]] in [[Tolosa, Spain|Tolosa]], 1948]] One scholar suggests that having moved with his newly wed wife to San Sebastián, Arrúe rejected proposals to live off perks and administrative positions.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 855</ref> Instead, he joined the anti-collaborationist Carlist faction loyal to Don Javier, and threw himself into rebuilding the independent Traditionalist network in the province. In 1940 he was appointed the representative of Gipuzkoa in a 4-member interregional vasco-navarrese junta;<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 855, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 194</ref> the same year the Carlist political leader [[Manuel Fal Condé|Manuel Fal Conde]] suggested he joins executive board of [[Editorial Navarra]], the Carlist publishing house disguised as a commercial enterprise.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 855</ref> In August 1942 as head of the Gipuzkoan junta he signed a manifesto prior to planned official celebrations commemorating the siege of Tolosa;<ref>also Fernando Aramburu as president of Diputación protested against the Francoist treatment of Gipuzkoa; he was forced out of office in October 1942, Teixedor 1990, p. 91</ref> the document urged loyalty to Don Javier and Fal, claiming that the future of Spain lies only with Carlism.<ref>Arrúe urged to “defender con todo su entusiasmo la bandera de la legitimidad, hoy en alto mantenida por nuestro Regente Don Francisco Javier de Borbón-Parma y su Delegado y único jefe de la Comunión Tradicionalista Sr.D. Manuel Fal Conde [...] ¡¡ Carlistas guipuzcoanos!! el próximo día 9 de agosto todos a Tolosa, a demostrar que aún se puede salvar a España con el carlismo y solamente con el carlismo”, quoted after Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 856</ref> As the event turned into riots between Carlists and Falangists, Arrúe – accused also of pro-[[Allied powers of World War II|Allies]] sympathies<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 856, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 274, see also [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E9PnPjp6iSc here]; for an anti-British view, see [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9TCN56ZUSD0 here]</ref> - was expulsed from Gipuzkoa and ordered a year of exile in [[Gijon]].<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 855, Zavala 2008, p. XIII he was fined, see Martorell Pérez 2014, p. 229</ref> [[File:Don Javier 1960.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Don Javier]], 1960]] In late 1940s Carlism lost its influence on Gipuzkoan [[:es:Diputación Foral de Guipúzcoa|Diputación]], FET and major local [[ayuntamiento]]s.<ref>Teixedor 1990, pp. 92-3</ref> Having returned to San Sebastían Arrúe resumed his semi-official Carlist activities; as the movement decomposed into many factions, he stayed loyal to Fal and the regent. He was with those judging that the regency aroused little enthusiasm amongst the rank-and-file and merely encouraged damaging dynastical competition; hence, he preferred that Don Javier announces his personal claim to the throne, which indeed took place in 1952.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 857</ref>
Arrúe maintained very good relations with the Carlist political leader; he shared Fal’s intransigence on dynastical and anti-Francoist issues, while Fal shared and supported Arrúe’s drive to promote the Basque identity.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, pp. 858-9, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 344</ref> Though in 1953 the Gipuzkoan junta was reconstituted under [[Ignacio Ruz de Prada]] and with [[Pablo Iturria]] as its secretary, it was in fact Arrúe remaining the provincial leader.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 858, Martorell Pérez 2009, pp. 343-4; the Gipuzkoan junta was not assembled for long periods, all powers resting with Arrúe, Vázquez de Prada 2012, p. 1124</ref> One scholar suggests that Arrúe conspired against Fal, considering him too conventional in his anti-Francoist bid;<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 392; the same author in his other work claims that Arrúe has been loyal to Fal, see Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 850</ref> if this is the case indeed, the ensuing deposition of Fal and collaborationist turn of mid-1950s caught Arrúe bitterly disappointed; he was leaning to a [[Maurici de Sivatte i de Bobadilla|Sivattista]] dissidence.<ref>he was present during the talks between Don Javier and the Sivattistas in Perpignan; the meeting ended with Don Javier signing a document pledging faith to Traditionalist principles and ruling out a dynastical agreement with the Alfonsists. The paper was supposed to be private, but Sivatte made it public. A number of signatories were later expulsed from the Comunion; Arrue was spared due to his recent appointment to the provincial jefatura, Mercedes Vázquez de Prada, ''El final de una ilusión. Auge y declive del tradicionalismo carlista (1957-1967)'', Madrid 2016, {{ISBN|9788416558407}}, pp. 45-46</ref> With [[José María Valiente Soriano|José María Valiente]] emerging as a new national jefe, in 1956 Arrúe tried to oppose his course by forming Junta del Regiones;<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 394; Martorell Pérez 2014, p. 112; a bit different view Mercedes Vázquez de Prada Tiffe, ''El nuevo rumbo político del carlismo hacia la colaboración con el régimen (1955-56)'', [in:] ''Hispania'' 69 (2009), pp. 193-196</ref> this semi-rebellious body was bent on preventing rapprochement with Francoism and envisioned a loose alliance of Carlists, nationalists, regionalists, Catholics and even some sectors of the Falange.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 859; Arrúe held separate talks with Arrese, bordered disloyalty to Don Javier, Vázquez de Prada 2009, p. 198</ref> The junta proved to be short-lived and some of its participants soon backtracked when challenged by Valiente, but Arrúe did not.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 859</ref> In 1957 as Gipuzkoan jefe he automatically entered the newly formed Junta de Gobierno de la Comunión<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2009, p. 199, Vázquez de Prada 2012, p. 1116; Bernardo Estornés Lasa, ''Antonio Arrúe Zarauz'', claims that Arrúe was also a member of “Junta suprema”, “Diputación permanente” and “Junta nacional” of the Comunión, but none of these bodies is identified or mentioned by other scholars</ref> and kept confronting the new leader, accusing him of betraying the Carlist spirit.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 859, he is described as “representante del sector más intransigente del carlismo vasco”, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 415</ref> In early 1959 he resigned as jefe of Gipuzkoan Carlism, quoting disagreement with policy of the new Secretariat.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, pp. 859-60, Martorell Pérez 2014, p. 113; it is not clear when Arrúe has earlier re-taken junta's presidency from Ruiz de Prada</ref>
==Late Francoism== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] The Gipuzkoan command was temporarily assumed by junta’s vice-president, [[Luis Zuazola]],<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2012, p. 1131</ref> but the Carlist king did not appoint a new jefe.<ref>a local commission, called in 1959 and composed of José Ignacio Olazábal, Elías Querejeta and Germán Raguán suggested that Luis Zuazola is the best candidate for the new jefe, Vázquez de Prada 2012, p. 1124</ref> In the early 1960s Arrúe remained the soul of provincial Traditionalism,<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2012, p.1132; the front-men were José Aramburu, José Ignacio Olazábal, Luis Zuazola and Germán Raguán Vázquez de Prada 2012, p. 1125</ref> apparently driving from the back seat<ref>according to Raguán Zuazola used to sign everything approved by Arrúe, Vázquez de Prada 2012, p. 1135; the author considers Gipuzkoan leadership team Arrúe’s camarilla, see Vázquez de Prada 2012, p. 1135</ref> though also assuming one-day prestigious ceremonial roles.<ref>in 1960, during celebrations of 125th anniversary of Zumalacarregui’s death, Arrúe addressed the crowd in front of the martyr’s mausoleum; speaking of course in Basque he underlined that no Spanish king is legitimate unless he swears to the Basque fueros, a hardly veiled reference to Don Javier’s oath taken in 1937, Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 863</ref> When the claimant decided to compete with Basque nationalism by setting up an inter-regional Vasco-Navarrese council named Junta Foral Superior in 1961, Arrúe was considered an obvious representative of Gipuzkoa<ref>along a veteran Gipuzkoan Carlist and former president of the Gipuzkoan Diputacion Provincial, Julián Elorza Aizpuru</ref> and a leading candidate to head the entire body. His opponents considered Arrúe a power-hungry Carlist version of [[José Antonio Aguirre (politician)|Aguirre]], keen to build his Vascongadas fiefdom,<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2012, pp. 1132-5</ref> and as there were no suitable counter-candidates, the idea of Junta Foral was eventually abandoned.<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2012, p. 1136</ref> In 1962 [[José Aramburu]] was formally appointed jefe provincial.<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2012, p. 1125</ref>
Sidetracking of Arrúe was acknowledged by the regime, always keen to exploit differences within various political groupings, by awarding him [[Orden del Mérito Civil]] in 1964.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 849, San Martin 1976, p. 16</ref> In mid-1960s Arrúe, from 1957 supporting Carlist prince [[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|Carlos Hugo]],<ref>In 1957 Arrúe supported the idea of [[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|Carlos Hugo]] making a surprise entry at [[Montejurra]], see Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 415, Martorell Pérez 2014, p 84; he was also in the first line during the ceremony itself, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 416, Martorell Pérez 2014, p 85. It is not clear why Arrúe supported the prince; maybe he considered Carlos Hugo and the hugocarlistas a counter-weight to Valiente, maybe he hoped that a young prince would provide more dynamics while Don Javier was already aging, maybe he viewed prince’s entry as a means of strengthening the dynasty against the Juanistas, especially that Arrúe has already pressed Don Javier on descendancy issues, Vázquez de Prada 2009, p. 198</ref> neared the group of his young entourage. He engaged in their new publishing house Ediciones Montejurra<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 863-4</ref> and in the spring of 1967 was rewarded with the privilege of addressing the annual Montejurra amassment, the key event in hugocarlista strategy of grabbing power within the Comunión and a promotional stage for Carlos Hugo himself.<ref>compare Jeremy MacClancy, ''The Decline of Carlism'', Reno 2000, {{ISBN|9780874173444}}, pp. 127-156</ref> Speaking as usual in Basque he focused on regional rights,<ref>note also the social thread: “las regiones fueron las constructoras de la nación y hoy son la columna viva que sostiene la sociedad en que vivimos,” quoted after Martorell Pérez 2014, p. 224; “sólo en la unidad de España tienen sus limites las libertades regionales”, quoted after ''La Vanguardia'' 13.05.67, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1972/08/24/pagina-7/34365458/pdf.html here]</ref> though his lecture arose little enthusiasm and there were even some jeers recorded.<ref>Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''El naufragio de las ortodoxias: el carlismo, 1962-1977'', Pamplona 1997, {{ISBN|8431315644}}, 9788431315641, p. 302, Vázquez de Prada 2016, p. 310</ref>
[[File:Carlos Hugo 1968.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|Carlos Hugo]], 1969]]
In late 1967 Arrúe stood as a Carlist<ref>there was much trust in the Comunion that Arrue would ensure the Carlist success in Gizpuzkoa, Vázquez de Prada 2016, p. 326</ref> in the newly introduced, semi-free elections to the [[Cortes Españolas|Cortes]] from the so-called [[:es:Organización municipal de España durante el régimen franquista|Tercio Familiar]],<ref>Martorell Pérez 2014, p. 250</ref> and defeated the governmental candidates in Gipuzkoa.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, pp. 850, 869, see also the official Cortes service [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%289240%29.NDIP. here]</ref> He immediately carried into the parliament the just-launched campaign to re-introduce concierto economico,<ref>the campaign was launched in by the Carlist councillors of the Tolosa ayuntamiento, Martorell Pérez 2011, pp. 864–5, 866</ref> though despite attempts to mount some public pressure,<ref>in 1967 he led a public gathering at the main plaza of Estella; flanked by immense portraits of Don Javier and Carlos Hugo and following a folk performance of Muthiko Alaiak, Arrúe addressed a see of boinas rojas; first in Basque and later in Castellano he declared that Carlism supports the campaign to restore the concierto</ref> the initiative came to nothing producing only minor alterations to the original abolition law.<ref>the government merely agreed to remove part of the preamble, which implied that Gipuzkoa and Biscay were punished for their pro-Republican stance in 1936; as the very text the Francoist government declared that there is no step back, Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 865</ref> As part of a hardly veiled dissident strategy, Arrúe joined [[:es:Procurador en Cortes|procuradores]] who, unable to get adequate hearing in the chamber, staged rump informal sessions across the country;<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 19.01.68, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1967/09/22/pagina-5/33575432/pdf.html here]</ref> this “Cortes transhumantes” was formally banned in 1968.<ref>Stanley G. Payne, ''The Franco Regime'', Madison 1987, {{ISBN|0-299-11070-2}}, p. 517</ref> In early 1969, together with 3 fellow Carlist MPs, Arrúe protested expulsion of Don Javier and Carlos Hugo.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 10.01.69, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1967/11/10/pagina-6/33570167/pdf.html here]</ref>
On July 22, 1969 Arrúe recorded the second of the two most emotional moments in his political career: in an open, one-by-one Cortes voting in front of Franco he voiced against [[Juan Carlos de Borbón]] as the future king of Spain.<ref>as one of 4 Carlists and 19 procuradore in total, Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 870; see the Pathe film with part of the procedure (starting 02:55), available [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qozc4xWE55E here]</ref> Paradoxically, at that time he was increasingly alienated by the pro-democratic turn of the dynasty he remained loyal to. Though when in 1970 Carlos Hugo established his ''Gabinete Ideologico'', Arrúe joined its foral commission, he remained in this body no longer than until 1971.<ref>Comisione Delegada Para el Estudio Foral y Local, Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 204</ref> Following a scandal related to re-election negotiations of the Navarrese MPs,<ref>[[José Ángel Zubiaur Alegre|José-Angel Zubiaur Alegre]] and Auxilio Goñi Donázar, two Carlist [[Member of parliament|MPs]] from Tercio Familiar who like Arrúe voted against declaring Juan Carlos in 1969, during preparations to the 1971 re-election campaign were required by Don Javier and his entourage to sign their undated resignations prior to running as Carlist candidates; enraged, they refused, see José-Ángel Zubiaur Alegre, José-Ángel Zubiaur Carreño, ''Elecciones a Procuradores familiares en Navarra en 1971'', [in:] ''Aportes'' 27/79 (2012), pp. 147-167</ref> he broke up with [[Carlist Party|Partido Carlista]], now firmly controlled by the socialist progressists,<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 863; he declared: “yo continuaré siendo carlista hasta la muerte. Pero con Carlos Hugo y los suyos no quiero saber nada”, quoted after Zavala 2008, p. XIII</ref> and did not run in the 1971 elections.<ref>it is not clear whether Arrúe was required to sign the same resignation letter as the Navarrese Carlist procuradores were; Zubiaur Alegre 2012 does not mention his name</ref> He kept considering himself a Traditionalist<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 863; „en politica fui siempre tradicionalista”, quoted after Zavala 2008, p. XII</ref> and an immense portrait of the Carlist king Javier I remained in his office.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 871</ref>
==Basque: promoter and organizer== [[File:Xalbador.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|[[:eu:Xalbador|Xalbador]], Arrue's favorite [[bertsolari]]]] Arrúe’s mother tongue was Basque and he spoke Basque also with his own children.<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XIX</ref> Little is known about his early views on the Basque question. In the 1930s he firmly opposed [[Partido Nacionalista Vasco|PNV]] and its political ambitions,<ref>“en primer lugar hizo uso de la palabra D. Antonio Arrúe, que habló en vasco, haciendo un llamamiento a los regionales para que no se dejen sorprender por las doctrinas que él califica de nuevas y que no son más que un morbo separatista,con las que la tradición está en abierta pugna”, ''El Sol'' 24.12.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000567224&page=8 here]</ref> confronting them with a traditionalist vision of ''[[Southern Basque Country|foral Euskalerria]]'' as an integral part of Spain;<ref>called “para luchar por Dios, por España y por Euskalerria”, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.02.36, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000575441&page=12 here]</ref> simultaneously he stood out by delivering all his speeches in [[Basque language|Basque]], at that time practiced only by some PNV politicians.<ref>San Martin 1976, p. 16</ref> As a leading Carlist politician in Gipuzkoa, during the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] and in the 1940s he showed a concern for Basque culture and for Basque provincial rights, though not for Basque political ambitions.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, pp. 851, 858-9, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 344</ref>
As some pre-war Basque cultural institutions were getting re-established in the [[Francoist Spain]], Arrúe was increasingly engaged in their activities. In 1953 he assumed co-directorship<ref>with [[:eu:Aingeru Irigarai|Aingueru Irigaray]] and [[Koldo Mitxelena]]</ref> of ''[[:eu:Egan (aldizkaria)|Egan]]'',<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 860, Bernardo Estornés Lasa, Antonio Arrúe Zarauz</ref> a review issued by [[Real Sociedad Bascongada de Amigos del País|Real Academia Vascongada de Amigos del País]]. It is in ''Egan'' that in 1954 he started to publish<ref>as ''A.A''.</ref> a regular column<ref>titled ''Jan edenak''; full archve available [http://andima.armiarma.com/egan/aurki.htm here]</ref> dedicated to [[cuisine]]<ref>Arrúe was a refined gourmet expert. He had a huge library on the subject, Zavala 2008, p. XVI, co-founded Cofradía Vasca de Gastronomía, Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 862, took part in conferences on gourmet, see ''La Vanguardia'' 12.11.68, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1961/10/21/pagina-28/34308337/pdf.html here] and won prizes for his writing on cuisine, ''La Vanguardia'' 17.12.63, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1972/08/24/pagina-28/32676336/pdf.html here]</ref> and maintained for over 20 years.<ref>his contributions were gathered and reprinted in 1979, Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 860</ref> The same year he commemorated fellow Carlist vascologist [[Julio Urquijo Ibarra]] by facilitating foundation of a Basque philology institute bearing his name.<ref>exercising whatever influence he still had in local politics, Bidador 2000</ref> When [[Euskaltzaindia]], the Basque language academy, managed to regain its precarious legal standing in the early 1950s, Arrúe neared the institution, to join it formally in 1954.<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XIII and San Martin 1976, p. 16 claim it was in 1954</ref> As a lawyer and a politician he was instrumental in organizing its first congress in [[Sanctuary of Arantzazu|Aránzazu]] in 1956,<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 860, Zavala 2008, p. XIII</ref> overcoming a number of legal, administrative and political obstacles.<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XIV, Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 861</ref> He also presided over many of its sessions<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XIV</ref> and was key to engineering the follow-up, vital to the re-launching of Euskaltzaindia after the Civil War.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 861</ref>
Relieved from political Carlist duties, in the late 1950s Arrúe fully dedicated himself to Euskaltzaindia. He was the moving spirit behind its newly established commission dedicated to [[Bertsolaritza|bertsolarism]]<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XV</ref> and promoted the genre<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 861</ref> by organizing local qualifications,<ref>in the immediate post-war era bertsolarim was reduced to very low-ley events, virtually family and friend meetings</ref> leading up to the final contest formatted as a major San Sebastián cultural event in 1960,<ref>''ABC'' 20.12.60, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1960/12/20/062.html here]</ref> 1962,<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XV, see also ''ABC'' 01.01.68, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1963/01/01/068.html here]</ref> 1965 and 1967.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 861, Zavala 2008, p. XV</ref> He was also a jury member,<ref>the circle of bertsolarismo promoters was formed by Juan María Lecuona, Alfonso Irigoyen, Fernando Artola, Antonio Valverde, Ambrosio Zaratain Juan San Martín and Antonio Zavala, Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 862, Zavala 2008, p. XV</ref> in case of discrepancies his vote often prevailing.<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XVI</ref> He facilitated a number of editorial initiatives, acknowledged in particular for the [[:es:Antonio Zavala|Zavala's]] 1961 launch of ''[[Colección Auspoa]]'' series<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011 p. 862</ref> and the 1964 re-print of ''[[:eu:Gero (Axular)|Gero]]'', a monumental 17th century Basque literary work.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 862; he also helped financially, see Zavala 2008, p. XVI, Bernardo Estornés Lasa, Antonio Arrúe Zarauz</ref> Some authors claim he also helped to push many works through the Francoist [[censorship]].<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XX, Luis Villasante, ''Antonio Arrue Zarauz (1903–1976)'', [in:] ''Jan-edanak'', Donostia 1979, {{ISBN|8472314677}}, 9788472314672, available also [http://zubitegia.armiarma.com/?p=mar-206 here]</ref> As an author he popularized Basque culture by writing<ref>also under the pen-name ''Urrea'', ''Arrue Zarauz, Antonio'' entry [in:] ''Harluxet hiztegi entziklopedikoa'', available [http://zubitegia.armiarma.com/?p=har-388 here]</ref> to ''[[La Voz de España]]'', ''Egan'', ''[[Euskera]]'', ''[[:eu:Euzko-gogoa|Eusko Gogoa]]'', ''[[El Fuerista]]'', ''[[:eu:Argia (aldizkaria)|Zeruko Argia]]''<ref>Bidador 2000</ref> and by delivering public lectures.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 864</ref>
[[File:Basque writers ca 1955.jpg|thumbnail|Arrúe, [[Pío Baroja|Baroja]] and [[Julio Caro Baroja|Caro Baroja]], 1955]]
In 1966 he was among initiators of the Euskaltzaindia memorandum to the Ministry of Education, suggesting pilot Basque classes in public schools, limited bilingualism in primary schools and graduation Basque classes in universities,<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 866</ref> apart from state subventions and limited introduction of Basque in official public use.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 867</ref> As a lawyer Arrúe assisted in [[Aránzazu congress of 1968]], vital for building the [[standard Basque|unified Basque language]].<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 869</ref> In 1969, when Euskaltzaindia’s legal standing was challenged, he threw himself into massive lawyer’s work, resulting in forming its firm juridical basis in 1972.<ref>Zavala 2008, p. XVII, Villasante 1979; the case was finally settled in 1976, Zavala 2008, p. XVIII</ref>
==Basque: theorist and practitioner== [[File:Egan.jpg|thumbnail|left|140px|''Egan'', 1967]] Arrúe, an amateur with no professional background either in [[linguistics]] or [[ethnography]], was in the second row of those scientifically contributing to the Basque culture. His works – articles published in Basque- and Spanish-language periodicals, mostly in ''Egan'' – are loosely scattered across many disciplines: history of [[Basque literature]],<ref>e.g. ''Juan Bautista Agirre'' (1954)</ref> history of Basque linguistics,<ref>e.g. ''Itzaurre-bidez'' (1956)</ref> [[grammar]] of Basque language,<ref>e.g. ''Gerriko'' (1956)</ref> Basque [[dialectology]],<ref>e.g. ''Euskareran batasuna'' (1956)</ref> history of Basque social movement,<ref>e.g. ''Palankariak'' (1958)</ref> Basque [[anthropology]],<ref>e.g. ''Euskal umoreaz'' (1961)</ref> theory of contemporary Basque [[poetry]],<ref>e.g. ''Cuatro poetas vascos actuales'' (1963)</ref> [[History of the Basques|Basque history]],<ref>e.g. ''San Sebastián y la Real Compaña Guipuzcoana de Caracas'' (1963)</ref> Basque cuisine<ref>e.g. ''Gastronomía vasca'' (1967)</ref> and foreign literature;<ref>e.g. ''Turoczi'' (1958)</ref> it was only the question of Basque political ambitions that he avoided – at least in the Francoist Spain – and usually approached only as part of the Carlist history.<ref>E.g. ''Zumalakarregi'' (1960)</ref>
Arrúe’s role in theoretical development of the Basque language and culture is perhaps dwarfed by his practical contribution. Since the 1930s he has been hailed by media, colleagues and Vascófilos as a great speechmaker,<ref>invited and wanted also abroad, see Zavala 2008, p. XVIII</ref> who has not only transplanted spoken Basque from barns to congress halls, but also brought it to unprecedented rhetorical mastery. Considered one of the best Basque orators of his time,<ref>Bernardo Estornés Lasa, ''Antonio Arrúe Zarauz''</ref> he was acknowledged not for highly emotional inflammatory style, but rather for smoothness, sense of humor, vivacity and fluidity.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 861, Zavala 2008, p. XVIII</ref> His practical contribution to written Basque, apart from scientific articles, covers also short poems, usually humorous light pieces like a praise of the [[Sherry|Jerez sherry]], occasionally winning prizes during local contests.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 24.08.72, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1972/08/24/pagina-4/33615834/pdf.html here]</ref> [[File:Bilboko Euskaltzaindia.jpg|thumbnail|160px|Euskaltzaindia site]]
==Basque: reception and legacy== Arrúe remained a rather forgotten figure until a compilation of his works was released in 2008 and triggered some follow up both in media and in historiography.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2011, p. 849; Arrúe’s friends and colleagues from Euskaltzaindia arranged for his works to be issued as a book in 2008; for a sample of press acknowledgements see ''[[Diario Vasco]]'' 03.05.09, available [http://www.diariovasco.com/20090503/cultura/hombre-saco-apuros-euskaltzaindia-20090503.html here]; brief historiographical debate ensued in ''Euskera'' of 2011 and 2012</ref> According to the recently published works his contribution to the Basque cause is highly controversial. It remains beyond any doubt that he opposed independent Basque political ambitions, defended integrity of Spain and has always considered the Basques part of the Spanish political nation; different views pertain to his intentions and to his impact on Basque culture and Basque national development.
In some studies Arrúe is presented as “one of us”, a Basque who trapped in political maze of his time did his best to promote Basque culture against the hostile background of Francoist regime. He is credited mostly for his support as organizer, lawyer and politician, a person who delivered an umbrella sheltering Basque institutions and enabling cultural development, shaped and directed by the others.<ref>see apologetic article by Manuel Martorell Pérez 2011 or the homage paid by Antonio Zavala 2008; [[:eu:Luis Villasante|Luis Villasante]] 1979 calls him friend and colleague and wishes “may he help for us from heaven”</ref>
[[File:Mikel Mikel zaitu Euskalerria.JPG|thumbnail|left|Euskalerria 2014]]
In some studies Arrúe is presented as “a vascófilo within the regime”, a person who tried to accommodate Basque cultural ambitions within the Francoist system. In this perspective, Arrúe appears to be either someone whose contribution was merely a byproduct of his Carlist political leaning, someone who unintentionally promoted the cause, or someone who was used by the Basques to pursue their cultural and national goals.<ref>see biographical note edited by [[:eu:Joxemiel Bidador|Joxemiel Bidador]] 2000 or ''Arrue Zarautz, Antonio'' entry at ''Lur hiztegi entziklopedikoa'' available [http://zubitegia.armiarma.com/?p=lur-388 here]</ref>
In some studies Arrúe is presented as a badly reputed "Asteasu beltza".<ref>very loosely translatable as “Darth Vader from Asteasu”; this approach is presented by [[:eu:Pako Sudupe|Pako Sudupe]], ''Antonio Arrue: Euskaltzaindiaren eta Francoren erregimenaren laguntzaile'', [in:] ''Euskera'' 57 (2012), pp. 823-838, based on own research and evidence provided by Nemesio Agapito Echániz Arambarri and Andima Ibiñagabeitia Idoyaga</ref> Adherent to a backward ideology, he censored the Basque literature,<ref>enforcing also self-censorship upon the authors, Sudupe 2012, p. 829</ref> forced pro-Francoist distortions,<ref>in re-issued edition of ''[[:eu:Peru Abarka|Peru Abarca]]'' the original prologue is replaced by the one written by Arrue, Sudupe 2012, p. 829</ref> promoted clericalism,<ref>Sudupe 2012, p. 831; the same author claims that Arrúe, in the best Soviet style, manipulated the clergy, see p. 836</ref> sponsored Spanish lexical intrusions into Basque,<ref>Sudupe 2012, p. 831</ref> obstructed disliked people and publications<ref>Sudupe 2012, p. 835</ref> and manipulated bertsolari contests in terms of their winners<ref>Sudupe 2012, pp. 834-5</ref> and in terms of their public reception.<ref>Sudupe 2012, p. 834 quotes Nemesio Echániz speaking allegedly on Arrúe: “En todas las fiestas populares euskéricas, un señor que ya desde antaño tenía dadas buenas muestras de su fobia hacia todos los que no se allanaran a sus estrechas ideas políticas, se arroga el derecho de soltar una soflama euskérica con latiguillos fáciles de un pretendido entusiasmo vasquista”.</ref> In a nutshell, according to this view Arrúe was nothing less than a Francoist “political commissar” delegated to Euskaltzaindia,<ref>Sudupe 2012, p. 834</ref> and his activity remained detrimental to Basque national development.<ref>see damaging accounts by Echániz and Ibiñagabeitia referred by Sudupe 2012, pp. 836-7</ref>

[[University of Wisconsin-Madison]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | footnotes= }} '''Brison Dowling Gooch''' (March 1, 1925 – November 25, 2014) was an American historian who was a [[professor emeritus]] of 19th-century European history at [[Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas]] (TAMU). He was an authority on the [[Revolutions of 1848]], [[Napoleon III]], [[Belgium]], and the [[Crimean War]]. ==Background== Gooch was one of six children to be born to Austin McLellan Gooch, a [[carpenter]], and the former Clara Helen Dowling,{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/oklahoman/obituary.aspx?pid=173321888#sthash.IzdLLg1T.dpufamid|title=Brison Gooch|publisher=''[[The Daily Oklahoman]]''|date=November 30, 2014|accessdate=January 14, 2015}} in [[Bar Harbor, Maine|Bar Harbor]] in [[Hancock County, Maine|Hancock County]], [[Maine]]. In the [[United States Army]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mainegenealogy.net/individual_enlistment_record.asp?id=30131|title=Maine Genealogy: The Enlistment Record of Brison D. Gooch|publisher=mainegenealogy.net|accessdate=October 18, 2010}} at the end of World War II, he served in Belgium and [[Germany]]. While in Germany, he attended the [[Nuremberg trials]] and heard discussions of German army atrocities in [[Russia]]. He received his [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree from [[Miami University]] in [[Oxford, Ohio|Oxford]], [[Ohio]]. Prior to his tenure at TAMU, which included terms as the history chairperson and associate dean of Liberal Arts, Gooch taught at [[Culver Military Academy]] and was a history professor at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], the [[University of Oklahoma Norman|University of Oklahoma at Norman]], and department head at the [[University of Connecticut at Storrs]]. In an academic career that spanned four decades, Gooch taught during summer sessions at the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University of Nebraska at Lincoln]], the [[University of Maine]], and the [[University of Wisconsin-Madison|University of Wisconsin at Madison]], where he had received both his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees. He also was a Carnegie visiting scholar for a year at [[Yale]] and Fulbright Faculty Research scholar in Belgium. Gooch's second wife, Shirley Jean Ferrell Black Gooch (April 20, 1935 – September 3, 1996), known professionally as Shirley J. Black, was also a TAMU professor of European history and highly active in the profession. ==Publications== *''The New Bonapartist Generals in the Crimean War'', 1959 *''Belgium and the February Revolution'', 1963{{cite web|url=https://www.questia.com/read/3461234|author=Brison D. Gooch |title=Belgium and the February Revolution|location=[[The Hague]], Netherlands | publisher=Martinus Nijhoff Publishers | year=1963 |accessdate=October 18, 2010}} * ''Napoleon III – Man of Destiny: Enlightened Statesman or Proto-Fascist?'', editor, 1966{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Napoleon-III--Man-Destiny-Proto-Fascist/dp/B0000CLW4N/ref=sr_1_12?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1287447071&sr=1-12|title=''Napoleon III – Man of Destiny: Enlightened Statesman or Proto-Fascist?''|publisher= Holt, Rinehart & Winston, 122 pp.|accessdate=October 18, 2010}} *''The Reign of Napoleon III'', 1969{{cite web|url=http://www.paperbackswap.com/Brison-D-Gooch/author/|title=List of books by Brison D. Gooch|publisher=paperbackswap.com|accessdate=October 18, 2010}} *''Interpreting Western Civilization'', 2 volumes, 1969,{{cite web|url=http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/360910|title=''Interpreting Western Civilization''|location=[[Homewood, Illinois]] | publisher= Dorsey Publishers | year=1969|accessdate=October 18, 2010}} editor *''Europe in the Nineteenth Century: A History'', 1970{{cite web|url=http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/1843256|title=''Europe in the Nineteenth Century: A History''|publisher= Macmillan Publishers | location=New York | year=1970 | accessdate=October 18, 2010}} *''The World of Europe Since 1815'', 1973, editor *''Interpreting European History'', 2 volumes, editor *''The Origins of the Crimean War'',{{cite web|url=http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/2519154|title=''The Origins of the Crimean War''|location=[[Lexington, Massachusetts]] | publisher=Heath Publishers | year=1969 | accessdate=October 18, 2010}} editor, 1969 *''Napoleonic Ideas'', editor Gooch contributed articles to a number of major historical journals, including the ''[[American Historical Review]]'', the ''[[Hispanic American Historical Review]]'', the ''Austrian History Yearbook'', ''Military Affairs'' and ''[[Victorian Studies]]''. ==Professional organizations== Gooch was active in various professional organizations, including the [[American Historical Association]] (AHA), and he attended many meetings and conventions during his career and also in retirement. In December 1969, he was elected to the nominating committee at the AHA annual meeting, and in 1979 was also elected by his colleagues as the president of the Southwestern Social Sciences Association.{{cite web|url=http://swhist.org/minutesy79.htm|title=Southwestern Historical Association, annual business meeting|location=[[Fort Worth, Texas]]|date=March 29, 1979|publisher=swhist.org|accessdate=October 18, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728075232/http://swhist.org/minutesy79.htm#|archive-date=2011-07-28|dead-url=yes|df=}} In 1974, Gooch was one of the founders of the [[Western Society for French History]] and served as its president in 1982. {{Infobox person | spouse = (1) Dorothy Gale Doll Gooch (married 1951-1974, divorced)
